com.telenav.kivakit.core.messaging.Broadcaster, com.telenav.kivakit.core.messaging.Listener, com.telenav.kivakit.core.messaging.MessageTransceiver, com.telenav.kivakit.core.messaging.Repeater, com.telenav.kivakit.core.messaging.Transceiver, com.telenav.kivakit.core.registry.RegistryTrait, com.telenav.kivakit.core.vm.JavaTrait, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.messaging.Receiver, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.messaging.Transmitter, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.naming.Nameable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.naming.Named, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.naming.NamedObject, SettingsStore, Serializable, Iterable<Object>
public class Deployment extends MemorySettingsStore implements Serializable

A deployment is a Named SettingsStore containing user-defined settings Objects.

The name of a deployment can be retrieved with name() and a description of its purpose with description(). The example below, has details on how settings information can be loaded and queried.

Deploying Applications

Deployments can be added to a DeploymentSet via DeploymentSet.addDeploymentsIn(ResourceFolder). The method deploymentSwitchParser(Listener, DeploymentSet, String) will create a command line SwitchParser that can select among several deployments in a DeploymentSet by name. This is handled automatically if the application places deployments in the application-relative package "deployments".

An application can then specify a deployment with the command line switch: 

 -deployment=production

Here, settings objects in the "production" Deployment will be installed into the global settings registry. At a later point, the application can look up those objects with SettingsTrait.lookupSettings(Class) and SettingsTrait.lookupSettings(Class, InstanceIdentifier), both of which are provided by the Component class in the kivakit-component project.

Example

The Demo application here loads a set of deployments, each of which is a set of .properties resources in a sub-package of the "deployments" package next to the Demo class: 

 Demo.class
 deployments/
     development/
         DemoSettings.properties
         RouterSettings.properties
     production/
         DemoSettings.properties
         RouterSettings.properties

It does this by using a SwitchParser from kivakit-application to allow the user to select a deployment from the command line. The deployment is automatically installed in the global SettingsRegistry registry, and these settings objects can easily be located in the code. The usage for the Demo application then, is: 

 java -jar Demo.jar -deployment=production

In the deployments.development and deployments.production sub-packages, there will be properties files for each deployment which are used to create and populate the required settings objects. One of the properties files in deployments/development might look like this:

AwsServer.properties

 class=com.telenav.navigation.my.application.ServerSettings
 port=aws.amazon.com:7001

When KivaKit loads this properties file, it will instantiate the ServerSettings class specified by "class" and configure the resulting object. It does this by using the @ConvertedProperty annotation to convert the value for the "port" key in the properties file into an object which it then passes to the annotated port(Port) method:

ServerSettings

 public class ServerSettings
 {
     private Port port;

    @ConvertedProperty(Port.Converter.class)
     public void port( Port port)
     {
         this.port = port;
     }

        [...]
 }

Once the deployment's settings information is all loaded into the global settings registry, any component in the project can then locate the configured object like this: 

 public class SomeOtherClass extends BaseComponent
 {
     public void doIt()
     {
         var settings = requireSettings(ServerSettings.class);

             [...]
     }
 }

For more details on how settings are processed and how applications can locate settings information, see SettingsRegistry.

Author:
jonathanl (shibo)
